questions.text: During the dark phase of the visual cycle, which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to form rhodopsin?
questions.solution:
Opsin combines with 11-cis-retinal to produce rhodopsin.

Only the retinal form of vitamin A is involved in the formation of the photopigment.

 

The common food sources of preformed vitamin A (retinol) are liver, kidney, egg yolk, and butter. Provitamin A (beta-carotene) is mostly found in green leafy vegetables, sweet potatoes, and carrots. Because vitamin A from animal sources or supplements is preformed, it is more likely to cause toxicity than the provitamin A from plant sources.

questions.text: The most common cause of cataract is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of cataract is aging, i.e., senile (age-related) cataract.

Senile Cataract:

  • Cuneiform (70%): Most common
  • Nuclear (25%)
  • Cupuliform/posterior subcapsular (5%): most visually handicapping

Important causes of cataract:

  • Congenital cataract: Crystallin gene - CRYAA, CRYAB, CRYGC, CRYGS
  • Aging (Most common)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Syndermatotic: Atopic dermatitis is the most common skin condition associated with cataract
  • Galactosemia: reversible cataract
  • Radiation: UV rays, X-rays, gamma rays, infrared
  • Toxic agents: Corticosteroids, miotics (long-acting anticholinesterases, e.g., echothiophate)
  • Obesity

questions.text: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in _______.
questions.solution:
Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO). 

They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaques in larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).

questions.text: Which of the following best defines saccades?
questions.solution:
Saccades are sudden, jerky eye movements that occur as the gaze shifts from one object to another.

They are performed to bring the image of an object quickly on the fovea.

The image below shows saccadic movement of the eyeball

Eye movements that have a supranuclear control:

  1. Saccades
  2. Pursuits- smooth eye movements
  3. Vergence movement system- slow, disconjugate movements
  4. Vestibular eye movement- compensate for the effects of head movements
  5. Optokinetic system- during sustained head rotation
  6. Position maintenance system- consist of rapid micromovements such as flicks and drifts

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

"Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes.

All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.

Features of papilledema:

  • Raised ICP
  • Edema of the optic nerve head
    • Blockage of axoplasmic flow
    • Axonal swelling
    • Collection of extracellular fluid
  • Painless progressive loss of vision
  • Enlargement of the blind spot
  • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.

questions.text: A young woman comes with sudden onset ocular pain, tearing, and photophobia in the left eye. You suspect a bacterial corneal ulcer. What concentration of cephazolin drops would you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
The concentration of fortified cephazolin used to treat uncomplicated bacterial keratitis is 5% ( 50 mg/mL)

Treatment of uncomplicated bacterial keratitis:

  • Antibiotic eyedrops (broad-spectrum)
  • If not responding, fortified antibiotic eye drops are used
    • Fortified cephazolin (5%)
    • Fortified tobramycin (1.3%)
    • Fortified vancomycin (5%)
  • Cycloplegic drugs- Preferably 1% atropine eye ointment or drops to prevent pain due to ciliary spasm. Also, it prevents the development of posterior synechiae.
  • Oral vitamin A and vitamin C help in the healing of the epithelium
  • Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs

Management of non-healing ulcers:

  • Debridement
  • Chemical cauterization- 10–20% trichloroacetic acid, carbolic acid
  • Conjunctival flapping

Management of impending perforation:

  • Decrease intraocular pressure (IOP) by antiglaucoma drugs
  • Tissue adhesive glue such as cyanoacrylate
  • Bandage contact lens
  • No strain

questions.text: A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referred to ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection. Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown is the typical "pie in the sky" defect or superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) are involved.

"Pie in the floor" defects refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. It is seen in the involvement of the superior fibers of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop).

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The PARK procedure is used in the correction of which of the following?
questions.solution:
PARK is a technique used for correcting astigmatism.

Photo-astigmatic refractive keratotomy (PARK) is performed using excimer laser for the correction of astigmatism. The other surgical procedures used for correction of astigmatism are astigmatic keratotomy, LASIK and SMILE.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is not associated with retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is associated with abetalipoprotenemia (Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome) and not with abetaglobulinemia.

 

Syndromes associated with RP (Atypical RP)
Usher syndrome  Sensory neural deafness + RP 

Bardet–Biedl syndrome 

(Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)

 Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Ocular myopathy and heart disease + RP
Refsum Syndrome   

Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
 

Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome

 Abetalipoprotenemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text: The final center for the horizontal movement of the eye is ______.
questions.solution:
The final center for the horizontal movement of the eye is the abducent nucleus.

  • Paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) is responsible for the horizontal gaze, which projects to the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.
  • The brainstem center for the vertical gaze is in rostral interstitial nucleus of Cajal in midbrain, above oculomotor nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a cause of pseudoptosis?
questions.solution:
Brow ptosis is a type of pseudoptosis, not ptosis.

Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. 

Types of ptosis:

  • Mechanical ptosis - Can be due to lid tumors, multiple/big chalazions, and conjunctival scarring
  • Aponeurotic ptosis - Due to dehiscence of the aponeurosis and in postoperative patients
  • Involutional ptosis seen in old age
  • Neurogenic ptosis due to a 3rd nerve palsy, Horner syndrome and synkinetic ptosis/Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking ptosis
  • Myogenic ptosis
    • Congenital: most common myogenic ptosis
      • Simple
      • Blepharophimosis syndrome
      • Congenital synkinetic ptosis
    • Acquired
      • Myasthenia gravis
      • Lambert–Eaton syndrome
      • Ocular myopathy

Causes of pseudoptosis (apparent ptosis):

  • Lack of support of the lids by the globe e.g. artificial eye, microphthalmos, phthisis bulbi, or enophthalmos.
  • Contralateral lid retraction
  • Ipsilateral hypotropia
  • Brow ptosis occurs due to excessive skin on the brow, or seventh nerve palsy, which is diagnosed by manually elevating the
    eyebrow 
  • Dermatochalasis

questions.text:
What is the distance between point A and B shown below?

DD - Disc Diameter
questions.solution:
In the image, point A is the optic disc and point B is the fovea. The fovea is situated about 2 disc diameters (3–4 mm) away from the temporal margin of the optic disc.

The optic disc is an area of about 1.5 mm. There is a blind spot / physiological scotoma, corresponding to the optic disc.

questions.text: The longest part of the optic nerve measures _____.
questions.solution:
Intraorbital part is the longest part of the optic nerve.

It measures from 25 mm to 30 mm.

Length of the optic nerve ranges from 3.5 cm to 5.5 cm.

80% of the fibers originate from the macular region.

Parts of optic nerve:

Parts

questions.text: A woman with pathological myopia visits the ophthalmology OPD for an annual eye check-up. What is the least likely finding to be seen on her ophthalmologic examination?
questions.solution:
The shallow anterior chamber is not a feature of pathological myopia.

Signs of pathological myopia include the following:

  • Prominent eyeballs
  • Large cornea
  • Deep anterior chamber (AC)
  • Fundus picture
    • Large, pale optic disc with the temporal myopic crescent
    • Degenerative changes in retina and choroid
    • Foster Fuchs spots (blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia)
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma
  • Degenerative changes in the vitreous—posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.solution:
Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children.

Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy. 

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Soft contact lenses are made of _____.
questions.solution:
Soft lenses are made up of hydroxyethyl methyl acrylate (HEMA).

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye.

Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

Other tests for dry eye include: 

  1. Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.
  2. Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye.
  3. Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. 

Other options:

Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour blindness. 

Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. 

Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double prism mounted on a slit-lamp.  

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: Pseudopapillitis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is seen in hypermetropia.

In hypermetropia, fundus examination shows an optic disc that is small, has ill-defined margins, appears highly vascular, and simulates papillitis. However, as the optic disc is not swollen, as seen in papillitis, it is also called pseudopapillitis. A shiny retina is seen due to the greater brilliance of light reflections known as shot silk appearance.

A fundus image showing the same is given below.

In hypermetropia or long-sightedness, incident parallel rays of light come to a focus behind the light-sensitive retina, with the accommodation at rest. It may be axial, curvatural, index, positional and due to the absence of a crystalline lens.

Patients can be asymptomatic when the refractive error is small and corrected by the use of accommodation. Sustained accommodative efforts can give rise to symptoms such as tiredness of the eyes, headache, watering and mild photophobia. It may also lead to esotropic (convergent) squint in children. When the hypermetropia is high enough to not be corrected by accommodative efforts, patients experience defective vision.

On examination, the size of the eyeball may appear small and the cornea is slightly smaller. The anterior chamber is comparatively shallow. Other features on fundus examination include a shot silk appearance, where the entire retina may shine due to reflected light. It is usually treated by using convex lenses, which help focus the light rays on the retina.

Other options:

Option A: Myopia or short-sightedness is a condition where parallel rays of light come to a focus in front of the retina. Fundus examination shows an optic disc that is large, pale and has a crescent at the temporal edge, degenerative changes in retina, choroid, vitreous and presence of posterior staphyloma.

Option C: Aphakia refers to the absence of a crystalline lens. Fundus examination only shows a hypermetropic, small disc.

Option D: Presbyopia is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation, leading to a progressive fall in near vision.

Related Pearl: Grading of Hypermetropia

American Optometric Association (AOA) has defined three grades of hypermetropia:

  • Low hypermetropia: error of + 2D or less
  • Moderate hypermetropia: error from +2.25D to + 5D 
  • High hypermetropia: error is > + 5D

Related Pearl: Surgical treatment of hypermetropia

Cornea based procedures

Lens-based procedure

Thermal laser keratoplasty (TLK)

Refractive lens exchange

Hyperopic photorefractive keratotomy

 Phakic intraocular lens 

Conductive keratoplasty

questions.text: What is the angle formed between the optic axis and visual axis at the nodal point?
questions.solution:
Angle alpha (α) is the angle between the optical axis and visual axis at the nodal point. 

Angle lambda (λ) is the angle between the pupillary axis and the line of sight.  It is the global tilt offset of the eye when it fixates on a specific target and is a response to the eccentric displaced position of the fovea from the geometrical center of the retina. (Option B)

Angle kappa (κ) is the angle between the visual axis and the pupillary line at the cornea. It is the only angle that can be measured and is of clinical significance. (Option C)

  • Positive κ is seen in pseudoexotropia
  • Negative κ is seen in pseudoesotropia

Angle gamma (γ) is the angle between the optical axis and the fixation axis at the center of eyeball rotation. (Option D)

  Visual axis Line of sight Fixation axis
Pupillary axis Kappa (κ) Lambda (λ)  
Optic Axis Alpha (α)   Gamma (γ)

questions.text: A preterm baby treated for respiratory distress syndrome is found to have white pupillary reflex on opthalmologic examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A preterm baby, treated for respiratory distress syndrome, with leucocoria (white pupillary reflex) most likely has retrolental fibroplasia.

Retrolental fibroplasia, also known as retinopathy of prematurity, is a proliferative retinopathy. Risk factors include prematurity, very low birth weight and supplemental oxygen therapy (given for respiratory distress syndrome). ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. 

Related Pearl: Potential adverse reactions to drugs administered in infants

Drug Side effect
Oxygen Retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia
Chloramphenicol Gray baby syndrome, bone marrow suppression
Vitamin K analogs Jaundice
Tetracycline Enamel hypoplasia
Sodium bicarbonate Intraventricular hemorrhage
Amphotericin Anuric renal failure
Indomethacin Oliguria, hyponatremia, intestinal perforation
Aminoglycosides Deafness, renal toxicity
Erythromycin Pyloric stenosis
Morphine Hypotension, urine retention

questions.text: Which of the following is used to differentiate pseudophakia from aphakia?
questions.solution:
Pseudophakia shows 4 images in the Purkinje image test, whereas aphakia shows only 2 images. Other features can be seen in both.

When aphakia is corrected with an intraocular lens implant (IOL), the condition is referred to as pseudophakia. Signs of pseudophakia with posterior chamber IOL include:

  • Surgical scar 
  • Anterior chamber slightly deeper than normal
  • Mild iridodonesis (tremulousness) of the iris
  • Purkinje image test shows 4 images
  • Pupil blackish in color but when the light is thrown in the pupillary area, shining reflex is observed

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images. Normally, 4 images are formed from four different reflecting surfaces i.e.

Image  Location Direction
Image 1 Anterior surface of the cornea Erect
Image 2 Posterior surface of the cornea Erect
Image 3 Anterior surface of the lens Erect
Image 4 Posterior surface of the lens Inverted

 

In aphakia, as the lens is absent, image 3 and image 4 are absent.

questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPD with visual complaints. What does it suggest?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive of papilledema.

Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema:

  • Early-stage:
    • Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first)
    • Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc
    • Mild hyperemia of the disc
    • The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer
  • Established papilledema:
    • The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped)
    • Macular fan appears
    • Paton’s lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nerve fibers
    • Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spot
    • Veins become tortuous and engorged
    • Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages
  • Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema:
    • The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork
    • Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface
  • Atrophic stage:
    • Secondary optic atrophy

questions.text: Purely depolarizing cells in the optic pathway are ________.
questions.solution: Amacrine cells are the cells that produce purely depolarizing potential and spikes.

questions.text: The normal extent of the visual field superiorly is ________.
questions.solution:
The extent of visual field superiorly is 50°

Normal extent of the visual field: 

  • Temporal: 90°/100°
  • Inferiorly: 70°
  • Nasal: 60°
  • Superiorly: 50°

Note: According to Parson's 22nd Ed., Page no. 101, the visual field extends 60o superiorly. However, most journals and other standard textbooks consider the answer to be 50o. Hence, we choose 50o as the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: In which disease is this particular pathology seen?
questions.solution:
The given picture depicts lenticonus.

In Alport’s syndrome, both anterior and posterior lenticonus are seen, but anterior lenticonus is more common.

Lowe’s syndrome is oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome characterized by

  • Congenital cataract
  • Glaucoma
  • Posterior lenticonus

questions.text: The second sight of old age is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Second sight of old age is seen in nuclear cataract.

  • Due to nuclear sclerosis, there is an increase in refractive index.
  • This leads to progressive myopia.
  • A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles.
  • This improvement in vison is termed as second sight.

Related Pearl: Important symptoms and their occurrence in cataract

Symptom Condition
Monocular diplopia or polyopia Cortical cataract (Incipient stage)
Color shift Nuclear cataract
Index hypermetropia Cortical cataract
Loss of ability to see objects in bright sunlight, blinded by the light of oncoming headlamps when driving at night Posterior subcapsular cataract and Nuclear cataract
Second sight/ Myopic shift/ Index myopia Nuclear cataract
Fluctuating refractive error Diabetic cataract (due to fluctuating blood sugar levels)

questions.text: What is a rigid intraocular lens made of?
questions.solution:
Rigid IOLs are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).

Depending on the type of material of manufacturing, 3 types of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOLs) are available:

  • Rigid IOLs are made entirely from polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).
  • Foldable IOLs are made of silicone, hydrogel, acrylic, and Collamer. These are implanted through a small incision. 
  • Rollable IOLs are ultra-thin IOLs made of acyrlic or hydrogel. These are implanted through a 1-mm incision after micro-incision cataract surgery technique.

questions.text: The most common type of congenital cataract with diminished vision is ______.
questions.solution:
Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment.

Etiology: It may be either genetic or environmental in origin.

  • Genetic pattern is usually of familial autosomal-dominant variety
  • Environmental form is associated with:
    • Vitamin D deficiency
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation may also cause lamellar cataract.
  • The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear.
  • Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.

 

Image: Lamellar cataract

questions.text: What signals are carried by the parvocellular pathway from the lateral geniculate body to the visual cortex?

choices.text: Colour vision, shape, and fine details

questions.solution:
The parvocellular pathway gives signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details. 

Feature Parvocellular Pathway Magnocellular Pathway
Arises  layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of LGB  Layers 1 and 2 of LGB
Terminates Layer 4 of visual cortex Layer 4 of visual cortex
Use  Color vision, texture, shape, and fine details Movement, depth, flicker, and spatial organization

LGB: lateral geniculate body

The interlaminar pathway gives signals for color vision to layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex having clusters of cells called blobs.

Photoreceptors
(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

questions.text:
An anxious primigravida with sickle cell trait comes to you for her first antenatal checkup. Which of the following is she at a higher risk of developing during the course of this pregnancy?
  1. Pre-eclampsia
  2. Abortions
  3. Urinary tract infections
  4. Placental abruptions
  5. Preterm labor
questions.solution:
Among the given options, patients with sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing urinary tract infections.

Sickle cell disease, on the other hand, is associated with increased risk of :

  • Miscarriages
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Preterm labor
  • Venous thromboembolism
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Placental abruption 
  • Fetal distress in labor

Note: Sickle cell trait is a benign condition in which the affected person has only one abnormal hemoglobin beta gene allele whereas, in sickle cell disease, the affected person has two abnormal hemoglobin beta gene alleles and is hence severely symptomatic. Unlike individuals with sickle cell disease, those with sickle cell trait do not have symptoms related to sickling and mostly lead a normal life.

questions.text: The following image represents the result after a patient underwent a Worth’s four-dot test. The most likely inference is ______.
questions.solution:
The given images likely suggest that the patient is suffering from right suppression.

Worth's four-dot test

  • Sensory function test
  • Patient wears goggles with
    • Red lens: Right eye
    • Green lens: Left eye
  • A box is viewed having 4 lights: one red, two green, and one white
  • Inference:
    • A: Normal—All 4 lights seen
    • B: Abnormal retinal correspondence—All 4 lights seen in the presence of manifest squint
    • C: Left Suppression—2 red lights seen
    • D: Right suppression—3 green lights seen
    • E: Diplopia—5 lights seen (2 red, 3 green)

questions.text: A patient with a known case of MI on aspirin comes with shortness of breath. She has an active history of asthma and uses inhalational bronchodilators, her last attack was 7 months ago. She was recently prescribed medications for increased intraocular pressure. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of asthma now presenting with shortness of breath after starting medications for increased intraocular pressure was most likely diagnosed with glaucoma. The drug she was likely prescribed was timolol, a non-selective beta blocker.

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals (beta-2 block on bronchi). They cause bronchospasms and are therefore contraindicated in patients with asthma (e.g. timolol, levobunolol). Ocular beta-blockers reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptors. Timolol is specifically associated with allergic blepharoconjunctivitis and punctal stenosis

Side effects: Systemic: Bronchospasm, bradycardia, decreased cardiac output, hypotension, depression, impotence, and altered lipid profile.

Contraindications: Asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, congestive heart failure, sinus bradycardia, and atrioventricular blocks

Other options:

Option A: The patient has been stable on aspirin for the past three years which is unlikely to be the cause of her current symptoms. 

Option B: Betaxolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma. 

Option C: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with optic atrophy?
questions.solution:
Leprosy is not associated with optic atrophy.

All the other given conditions can cause optic atrophy.

Causes of optic atrophy:

  • Primary optic atrophy
    • Optic neuritis
    • Compression by tumors and aneurysms
    • Hereditary optic neuropathies
    • Toxic and nutritional optic neuropathies
    • Trauma
  • Secondary optic atrophy
    • Chronic papilledema
    • Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy
    • Papillitis
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive retinal photocoagulation
    • Retinitis pigmentosa
    • Prior central retinal artery occlusion
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following is a wrong statement regarding diplopia?

choices.text: Anisometropia is a cause for binocular diplopia.
Crossed diplopia occurs in convergent squint.
Incipient cataract is a cause for uniocular diplopia.
Harmonious diplopia refers to uncrossed binocular diplopia.

questions.solution:
Crossed diplopia is seen in a divergent squint, as in medial rectus paralysis.

Binocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by both eyes.

Causes:

  • Anisometropia
  • Paralysis of extraocular muscles; commonest
  • Mechanical restriction of movements

Types:

 Uncrossed—Harmonious

  • False image on the same side of the deviation
  • Seen in convergent squint

Crossed—Unharmonious

  • False image on the opposite side of the deviation
  • Seen in divergent squint

Uniocular diplopia: Simultaneous perception of two images of a single object when seen by a single eye.

Causes:

  • Subluxated clear lens
  • Subluxated intraocular lens (IOL)
  • Double pupil
  • Incipient cataract
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: Which of the following defects is implicated in Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
In Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternal mitochondrial DNA. Therefore the condition has a maternal inheritance. 

LHON causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision. The characteristic visual field defect is a centrocaecal scotoma. Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of the disease. Optic neuritis and optic atrophy start in one eye and goes on to involve the other eye subsequently. It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years. The diagnosis of LHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age.

Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even years later. 

Note: LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromuscular dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. Which of the following statements best describes the pathology?

(NSR- Neurosensory retina , RPE- Retinal pigment epithelium)

choices.text: Fibrovascular membranes in the vitreous causing traction
Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to retinal tear
Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to choroidal exudation

questions.solution:
The prodromal symptoms of flashing lights, floaters followed by loss of monocular vision (curtain over the eye) and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between NSR and RPE due to a retinal tear.

Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment. It occurs due to fluid accumulation after a retinal break (tear). High myopia, trauma, pseudophakia, aphakia are predisposing factors. Patients present with photopsia (flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break), floaters and visual field defect (black curtain/veil in front of the eye). 

Signs include hypotony, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE and Shafers sign or tobacco dusting (pigments in the anterior vitreous). The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations. The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. 

Treatment is by prophylactic laser barrage, scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy and pars plana vitrectomy. 

Other types of retinal detachment are tractional and exudative type:

Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. It is seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eales disease and ROP. The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen. Treatment is with pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

Exudative retinal detachment is seen when exudative fluid from the choroid collects in the subretinal space. Patients present with visual field defects, floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia. The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen. Shifting fluid is seen. 

The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with tear at 3:30.

questions.text: Weiss operation is done in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Weiss operation is done in senile entropion. In this operation, the transverse lid split, and everything sutures are placed.

Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid.

Causes include:

  • Horizontal lid laxity
  • Vertical lid instability
  • Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure
  • Orbital septum laxity

Related Pearl: Surgical Modalities Used in Correcting Entropion

Cicatricial entropion

Senile entropion

Anterior lamellar resection

Transverse everting suture

Tarsal wedge resection

Weiss operation

Transposition of the tarsoconjunctival wedge. (Modified Ketssey’s operation)

Plication of lower lid retractors (Jones operation).

Posterior lamellar graft

Quickert procedure

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of Eale’s disease?
questions.solution:
Eale’s disease is an idiopathic inflammatory venous occlusion (phlebitis) that primarily affects the peripheral retina that is periphlebitis and is characterized by recurrent bilateral vitreous hemorrhage.

Superficial retinal hemorrhages and cotton-wool spots can be sometimes seen, but they are not characteristic of Eales disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent for blepharitis acarica?
questions.solution:
Blepharitis acarica is caused by Demodex folliculorum.

Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the margins of the lids.

The two types are

  • Anterior
    • Seborrheic and ulcerative types
    • Caused by staphylococci, mainly
  • Posterior – Mebomianitis

Occasionally caused by

  • Demodex folliculorum – Blepharitis acarica
  • Crab louse – Phthiriasis palpebrarum

The following image shows swollen and inflamed eyelid suggestive of blepharitis.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A neonate with leukocoria and strabismus is diagnosed to have persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV). Which of the following congenital disorders is it associated with?
questions.solution:
Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is associated with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

PHPV is a developmental disorder of the vitreous humor. In this condition, there is persistence of the embryonic hyaloid vessel. 

  • Anterior PHPV - Here, the remnant vessel is attached to the back of the lens but does not reach the optic nerve. 
  • Posterior PHPV- In this form of the disease, the vessel arises from the optic nerve. 

Clinically, PHPV presents with leucocoria and microphthalmia, and there can be complications such as tractional retinal detachments. 

This condition has a poor prognosis regardless of the time of intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes.

Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty, followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence of hypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy.

First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 is done at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus is every year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months.

The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.

questions.text: A mother noticed that her child has had malaligned eyes since birth but she couldn't afford treatment due to financial constraints.  She now presents at 2-months of age and the child has the following finding on examination. An ophthalmoscopic examination under full cycloplegia reveals no abnormalities in refraction and media. Cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Angle of deviation is large and constant.
Amblyopia develops in 90 % of the cases.
It is associated with latent vertical nystagmus.
Correction by spectacles is the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The age at presentation, esotropia, no refractory error, no media opacities, and no cranial nerve palsies suggest a diagnosis of essential infantile esotropia. The angle of deviation in infantile esotropia is fairly large (> 30°) and constant.

Infantile esotropia, also known as non-accommodative esotropia is the most common type of congenital esotropia.

Clinical features:

  • Comitant convergent squint
  • Age of onset- 1 to 2 months
  • Angle of deviation- large and constant
  • Amblyopia- develops in 25–40% of cases
  • Associations include:
    • Inferior oblique overaction
    • Dissociated vertical deviation (70%)
    • Latent horizontal nystagmus

Treatment:

  • Surgery- treatment of choice
  • Amblyopia correction measures: Patching of normal eye
  • Recession of both medial recti
  • Timing: Preferably before 1 year

questions.text: A mother noticed the following finding in her 3-month-old child. There is a history of watering  and discharge from his right eye since birth. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
questions.solution:
The image showing  right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage with topical antibiotics.

Congenital dacryocystitis is chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborn infants. It occurs due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. More than 90% of patients with undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

Treatment of congenital dacryocystitis depends on the age of the child:

  • Less than 9 months: Massaging (Crigler’s massage which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the sac) and antibiotic eye drops
  • 9 months to 4 years: Probing
  • Older children (> 4 years): Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) gives the best result. In DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.

questions.text: A young man presented with watering, redness and photophobia. He had similar complaints in the past which improved with self-medicated topical drops. His best-corrected visual acuity is 6/36 improving to 6/24. Slit-lamp examination revealed a 3 mm × 2 mm epithelial defect in the paracentral part of the cornea that stained positive with fluorescein dyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of spring catarrh. Slit-lamp examination finding of shield ulcer is typical of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or warm weather conjunctivitis (another name of VKC).

Shield ulcers are transverse ulcers seen in the upper cornea due to epithelial macroerosions in VKC. It is a rare complication of VKC and should always be kept in mind for patients suffering from vernal conjunctivitis.

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon- resembles arcus senilus; has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC is mainly with allergy avoidance and lid hygiene. Cool compresses, topical antihistamines, topical NSAIDs and topical steroids can be used to reduce the intensity of symptoms. 

The image given below shows a shield ulcer in a patient with VKC.

questions.text: In which of the following cataract surgeries is a self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision used?
questions.solution:
The self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made in small-incision cataract surgery (SICS).

SICS is a type of extracapsular cataract extraction techniques (ECCE). In these techniques, the major portion of the anterior capsule with the epithelium, nucleus, and cortex are removed, leaving behind the intact posterior capsule.

Note: Newer cataract surgeries include femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS), micro-incision cataract surgery (MICS) and Phaconit. FLACS is a microincision cataract surgery or a micro-phacoemulsification where a femtosecond laser is used to make the corneal incisions, perform capsulorhexis and fragment the lens. MICS refers to the phacoemulsification techniques that can be performed through a microincision (<2 mm). Phaconit is the term for the bimanual micro-phacoemulsification done with the needle incision technique through an incision of <1mm.

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text: During a visit to the ophthalmology department, you see the following test being performed for visual field charting of a patient. Identify the instrument used from the options given below.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a Lister's perimeter. It is used in manual perimetry for visual field charting

Classification:

  • Manual: Confrontation, Listers, Campimetry, Goldmann perimeter
  • Automated: Octopus, Field Master, Humphrey Field Analyzer
  • Static: Friedman, Automated
  • Kinetic: Confrontation, Listers, Scotometry, Goldmann

The best type is automated perimetry.

questions.text: What is the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum of the human eye?
questions.solution:
The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm.

Theories of color vision: 

  • Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different spectral sensitivities.
  • Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green).
  • Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a black-and-white picture.

questions.text: A slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. It is also noted that these yellow-white vitreous opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile. All of the following statements about this condition are true except:
questions.solution:
The examination findings are suggestive of asteroid bodies/hyalosis. It is not common in myopes.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

Only one eye is affected in 75% of patients; it rarely causes visual problems and the majority of patients are asymptomatic. The cause of asteroid hyalosis is unknown, but it has been associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The prevalence of asteroid hyalosis increases with age and affects 3% of those aged 75–86 years. It is more common in men than in women. While treatment of asteroid hyalosis is usually unnecessary, vitrectomy may occasionally be indicated.
